item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 1: "Beginnings"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: [display_podcast] Here's the first episode of our podcast "The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour". Listen or download above or stream it from ESL Radio*. Playlist is below. We tried to get a good cross-section of the types of music we like to spin, but there's still lots we couldn't fit into a one hour podcast! intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Booker T. and the MG's were one of the main inspirations for us to start Hot Can (Fela was the other), so it seems appropriate to let them introduce each show as well as the podcast overall and something about "Hip Hug-Her" just seemed right. Arguably the most influential band of the 60's. In addition to playing on numerous hits for the Stax and Volt labels, they also counted both The Beatles and The Velvet Underground as fans. How's that for credibility? Cymande, "Bra", Cymande; Janus Records, 1972 Criminally under appreciated in their time, Cymande should be a household name today. Anytime I hear a DJ spin a cut by them, someone always asks who it is. They had a smooth, confident sound that's incredibly fun and catchy. Hip hop aficionados will recognize this as a sample source for "Change In Speak" by De La Soul. Wheedle's Groove, "Everything Bad Is Good", Kearney Barton; Light in the Attic, 2009 An all-star lineup of Seattle funk musicians assembled by Light in the Attic to promote their comp of the same name featuring vintage sides from Seattle's funk hey day in the 60's and 70's.  Hopefully they'll get together again someday to recored Kearney Barton 2! Grant Green, "The Selma March", His Majesty King Funk; Verve, 1965 Even though Green cut most of his records for Blue Note, he did record for other labels on occasion. This track is from his one outing on Verve and check out the organ work from fellow Blue Note stalwart Larry Young. Ramsey Lewis, "Jungle Strut", Sun Goddess; Columbia, 1974 Lewis teams up with Maurice White and other members of Earth, Wind and Fire for this set. Herbie Hancock, "Watermelon Man", Head Hunters; Columbia, 1973 After a series of increasingly adventurous albums for Warner Brothers and Columbia in the early 70's, Hancock brought things back to earth a somewhat on Head Hunters. Black Heat, "Chip's Funk", Black Heat; Atlantic, 1972 Idris Muhammad, "Express Yourself", Black Rhythm Revolution; BGP Records, 1970 Cover songs are something we like a lot. Whether it's a Top 40 hit getting a greasy soul jazz make over or some jazz guys tackling an R&B grooving like Idris Muhammad does on this classic by Charles Wright and the Watts 103rd Street Rhythm Band, a good melody and a catchy groove never fail get our attention. This is one of two covers in this episode (well, three if count Herbie Hancock "covering" Watermelon Man with the Head Hunters) and there will likely be many more down the road. Chico Hamilton, "For Mods Only", Sounds from the Verve Hi-Fi; Verve, 2001 Herbie Mann, "Philly Dog", Live at the Whiskey A Go Go; Atlantic, 1968 The second cover from this episode is an extended workout on the Rufus Thomas classic. Great mid-tempo groover with some absolutely outrageous guitar work from Sonny Sharrock. *The Boogoos, "Theme From Isaac Kirya", Contemporary Afro Beat; Tramp Records, 2011 Other than the fact that they're based in Munich, I haven't been able to find out much of anything about this contemporary afro beat group, or, for that matter, who Isaac Kirya is and why this is his theme. Kind of refreshing these days. *Los Llamas, "Siboney", Si Para Usted: The Funky Beats of Revolutionary Cuba, Vol. 2; Waxing Deep/Light in the Attic, 2010 This set, as well as the first volume, do a lot to prove that there's way more to Cuban music than mambo and Buena Vista Social Club. *Jimmy McGriff,  "Back On The Track", Portrait; Blue Note, 197? This track originally appeared on McGriff's "Electric Funk" album which featured composer and electric pianist Horace Ott alongside the B-3 master. * - Due to programming constraints over at ESL Radio we had to cut the last three songs from this episode for the version streaming over there but they're still available here at hotcan.info.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 2: "Groove and Move"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: [display_podcast] More from the crates… Some deep cuts this week, some a little less deep. All of it's pretty fine though. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Richard 'Groove' Holmes, "Dumpy Mama", Theme from the Six Million Dollar Man and Other Selections; Flying Dutchman, 1975 Geraldo Pino and the Heartbeats, "Heavy, Heavy, Heavy", Let's Have A Party; Soundway, 2005 JD and the Evil's Dynamite Band, "Heavy, Heavy… Heavy", Explodes Across the Nation; Soul Fire, 2001 Donald Byrd, "Mr. Thomas", Black Byrd; Blue Note, 1973 The Mebusas, "Son of Mr. Bull Dog", Afro Baby: The Evolution of the Afro-Sound in Nigeria 1970-79; Soundway, 2004 The Jimmy Castor Bunch, "E-Man Par-Tay", Maximum Stimulation; Atlantic, 1977 Gene Ammons, "Mellow Gravy", The Best of Gene Ammons with Brother Jack McDuff; Prestige, 1962 Alabama Shakes, "Be Mine", 7" single b/w You Ain't Alone; Third Man Live, 2012 Charles Earland, "Smiling", Live at the Lighthouse; Prestige, 1972 Lou Donaldson, "Bag of Jewels", Midnight Creeper; Blue Note, 1968 Jr. Walker & the All Stars, "Groove and Move", A Gasssss; Atco, 1970 *King Curtis, "Games People Play", Duane Allman: An Anthology; Capricorn, 1972 (originally released on Curtis' Instant Groove; Wounded Bird, 1969) * - Once again we've got a bonus cut. In order to meet the time constraints for ESL Radio we had to remove some stuff. At least this time it was only one song, but what a song! Full show still available here.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 4: "Y Sharp"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: [display_podcast] Earthy grooves for the soul. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Big John Patton, "Hot Sauce", Blue John; Blue Note, 1963 Herbie Hancock, "Blind Man, Blind Man", The Blue Note Re-Issue Series; Blue Note, 1975 Lee Morgan, "The Sidewinder", The Sidewinder; Blue Note, 1963 Brother Jack McDuff, "Mac-Duffin'", Gin and Orange; Cadet, 1969 Osibisa, "Y Sharp", Woyaya; Decca, 1971 Kings Go Forth, "You're The One", The Outsiders Are Back; Luaka Bop, 2010 Freddie Hubbard, "Mr. Clean", Straight Life; CTI, 1971 O'Donel Levy, "You've Made Me So Very Happy", Black Velvet; Groove Merchant, 1970 *Cannonball Adderly, "Mercy, Mercy, Mercy", Mercy, Mercy, Mercy!; Capitol, 1966 * - I almost didn't include this one because there's a ton of surface noise on my copy. It's one my dad bought in the late 60's shortly after it first came out so I figure it's been played a bunch and well loved! Also another bonus cut of sorts since we had to cut it from the show to fit ESL Radio's format. Enjoy!

item.title: Donald "Duck" Dunn
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: Today we lost one of the inspirations for our DJ partnership and, by extension this podcast, when Donald "Duck" Dunn passed away while on tour in Japan at age 70. As the bass player for Booker T. and The MG's Dunn was a member of one of the seminal groups in American music. I first became aware of Donald "Duck" Dunn when I was in sixth or seventh grade and saw "The Blues Brothers" for the first time. It's impossible for me to state how much the music in "The Blues Brothers" affected me. It functioned as such a fundamental point of departure for the discovery so much amazing music that without it I can't imagine what my musical life would be like. The dubbed copy I borrowed from a friend didn't leave my family's VCR for months. I think I watched almost every day after school for ages. Blues, R&B, Soul and whatever combination of those three you can come up with were first introduced to me in a big way in that movie. The cameos by James Brown, John Lee Hooker, Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles and Cab Calloway are important and iconic in their own right, but the musical heart of the movie belongs to Jake and Elwood and their band. Dunn was right there in the middle of it as part of the rhythm section. In a movie stuffed to the gills with cool cats, Dunn was the coolest motherfucker of them all! Just check the screen capture of him up top from the closing credits playing "Jailhouse Rock" and smoking a pipe like being in the slammer is just another gig! At the time I had no idea who he was or what he'd done. He just seemed to look like how all bass players should, and he played that way too. Powerful enough to turn goat piss in to gasoline indeed! One of my favorite things I've ever read about music was something Greil Marcus wrote in the liner notes for a CCR anthology about John Fogerty's songwriting. I don't have it handy so I'll paraphrase what he wrote: "It's about as contrived as the weather". I think what he's getting at is a description of music that comes from a place so collectively deep inside all of us that it seems as though it's always been there. It's music that seems that it couldn't possibly come from just a few people even though it did. Music who's genesis we can't quite fathom and we just accept it as fact the way we accept a summer breeze or winter snow storm. It has a natural logic that just makes sense. It's a good way to describe Fogerty's songwriting and it's a good way to describe the music Booker T. Jones, Steve Cropper, Al Jackson and Donald Dunn made. Whatever that ineffable quality we ascribe to music that we like to call "soul" actually is, those four men had it in large quantities. It's definitely a quality present in Dunn's bass playing which seemed so effortless, elegant and timeless. When we set out on this project we call Hot Can all we knew was that we wanted it to encompass whatever we felt fell in between Booker T. and the MG's and Fela Kuti. I don't think we really stopped to think about what that meant. We've just used that idea as a guideline to forge whatever this aesthetic is. When we started the podcast there wasn't any deliberation about what the theme song would be. "Hip Hug-Her" was picked just because it seemed right, or as Dunn maybe would have said: "If the shit fits, wear it!" The shit fit, and we proudly wear it.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 7: "Funky Doo"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week's show kicks off with a live cut from The Crusaders before moving on to a couple of tunes that explore some of the sounds of the nascent jazz fusion movement. Reuben Wilson brings it back to the inner city before Herbie Mann heads out to the country and Steve Cropper goes even further into the wilderness. A trio of afrobeat tunes keep things moving before Hubert Laws and company get atmospheric and moody. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 The Crusaders, "Scratch", Scratch, Blue Thumb Records, 1974 Cedar Walton, "The Electric Boogaloo Song", The Electric Boogaloo Song, Prestige, 1969 Eddie Harris, "Funky Doo", High Voltage, Atlantic, 1969 Reuben Wilson, "Inner City Blues", Groove Merchant Presents, Groove Merchant, 197? Herbie Mann, "Blind Willy", Muscle Shoals Nitty Gritty, Embryo, 1970 Steve Cropper, "Rattlesnake", With A Little Help From My Friends, Volt, 1971 J.M. Tim & Foty, "Douala By Night", Ouelele: Another Collection Of Modern Afro Rhythms, Comet Records, 1999 Babatunde Olatunji, "Dominira", Soul Makossa, Paramount Records, 1973 Tunji Oyelana and the Benders, "Ifa", World Psychedelic Classics 3: Love's A Real Thing: The Funky Fuzzy Sounds Of West Africa, Stones Throw/Luaka Bop, 2005 Hubert Laws, "The Crying Song", The Crying Song, CTI, 1969

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 8: "Bumpin' On Sunset"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week on the show we take a listen to a variety of guitar players. From the Hungarian Gypsy Jazz master Gabor Szabo to the Juju stylings of Ebenezer Obey we cover a lot of ground in this episode. Check it out! intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Mel Brown, "Shanty", Chicken Fat, Euphoria, 1967 Gabor Szabo, "Spellbinder", Spellbinder, Impulse, 1966 Ivan 'Boogaloo Joe' Jones, "Brown Bag", Cold Sweat: From Jazz to Soul 'n' Funk to Blaxploitaion, Brown Sugar, 2004 Wes Montgomery, "Bumpin' On Sunset", Tequila, Verve, 1966 Kenny Burrell, "A Streetcar Named Desire", 'Round Midnight, Fantasy, 1972 Grant Green, "Old Man Moses (Let My People Go)", Iron City, Cobblestone, 1967 Chief Commander Ebenezer Obey, "A Fi Eni Oluwa Koyo (He Who God Delivers)", Juju Jubilee, Shanachie, 1985 Sir Victor Uwaifo, "Idogo (Ekassa 42)", Guitar Boy Superstar: 1970-76, Soundway,2008 Oliver de Cocque and His Expo '76, "The Tragedy of Two Friends", Lagos Chop Up, Honest Jon's Records, 2005 Jeff Beck, "Freeway Jam", Blow By Blow, Epic, 1975

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 10: "Lotus Flower"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week we've got an eccentric mix of Latin grooves, Blaxploitation atmospherics and Afro-fuzz freak outs amongst other things. item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 12: "Open Country Joy"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week we jump into the murky waters of 70's Jazz Fusion, not always the most critically acclaimed of styles. As primarily a mash up of jazz and rock, Fusion fell in a gap between the two and was generally disdained by critics from both sides. Much of the rub against Fusion stemmed from it's increasing focus on virtuosic musicianship and commercial pandering as the 70's wore on. Rock critics tended to be a bit more generous early on while Jazz critics generally saw the adoption of funk and R & B rhythms along with the use of electric guitars and synthesizers as some kind of affront to the "purity" of Jazz. While some of their criticisms were certainly justified, judged on it's own merits Fusion did produce some great music. This isn't meant to be an exhaustive look, just a look into a genre of music a lot of people pass over because it has a crummy reputation. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Miles Davis, "Duran", Directions; Columbia, 1980 Recorded during the sessions for 1970's A Tribute to Jack Johnson but not released until a decade later, "Duran" features some ferociously fuzzed out guitar work from John McLaughlin. Herbie Hancock, "Hidden Shadows", Sextant; Columbia, 1973 Herbie and crew get way out on this cut from his first record for Columbia. The Tony Williams Lifetime, "There Comes A Time", Ego; Polydor, 1971 Williams rose to prominence in Jazz circles while playing with Miles (and Hancock) in the 60's before leading his own group Lifetime in the 70's. One of the few fusion groups to regularly incorporate vocals. Jean-Luc Ponty, "Twenty Small Cigars", King Kong: Jean-Luc Ponty Plays The Music Of Frank Zappa; Liberty Records, 1970 Ponty would record more explicitly fusion-y records after this one but this one off collaboration with Zappa is interesting for it's close adherence to the arrangements Zappa used on his own recordings of these tunes. Deodato, "Black Dog", First Cuckoo; MCA, 1975 Deodato wasn't normally associated with the Fusion movement, he was more of a funky Jazz cat, but his disco-jazz take of this classic from Led Zeppelin qualifies. Eleventh House, "Adam Smasher", Introducing The Eleventh House with Larry Coryell; Vanguard, 1974 This one seemed like a good choice given the recent developments at CERN with the Large Hadron Collider. Return To Forever, "Jungle Waterfall", No Mystery; Polydor, 1975 Led by Chick Corea (yet another veteran of Miles' late 60's bands) RTF is the fusion band I generally love to hate, mostly because they have songs with titles like "Hymn of the Seventh Galaxy" and "Space Circus" which makes it a little hard to take them seriously. They did put out a couple of cool records with the Corea/DiMeola/Clarke/White line-up in the mid-70's. Billy Cobham, "Quadrant 4", Spectrum; Atlantic, 1973 Lenny White, "Mating Drive", Venusian Summer; Wounded Bird Records, 1973 Lenny White was the drummer in Return To Forever and Billy Cobham was the first drummer for the Mahavishnu Orchestra. I should've switched these two, apologies. Mahavishnu Orchestra, "Open Country Joy", Birds Of Fire; Columbia, 1972 The intro to this one is one of the few mellow points on Mahavishnu's second album.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 15: "Nigeria 70"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week I take a dive into Strut's awesome "Nigeria 70" series, the first volume ("The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos") of which is what sent me down the Afrobeat path. I picked up the CD at the now closed Broadway location of Kim's in NYC probably around 2002. At the time I didn't know anything about African music and had only heard of Fela and King Sunny Ade. The cover sold me instantly: A few years later Strut fell on hard times and the label shut down. Thankfully !K7 came to the rescue and revived the Strut imprint. Although most of the original Strut and AfroStrut titles are unfortunately still out of print, they've continued the "Nigeria 70" series with two stellar editions: "Lagos Jump: Original Heavyweight Afronbeat, Highlife & Afro-Funk" in 2007 and "Sweet Times: Afro-Funk, Highlife & Juju from 1970's Lagos" a year later. Since The Hunch recently acquired the decent copy of the first volume on vinyl, it seemed like a good time to take a listen to these stellar compilations. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Orlando Julius And The Afro Sounders, "Alo Mi Alo (Parts 1 & 2)", Nigeria 70: The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos; Strut, 2001 Segun Bucknor & His Revolution, "La La La", Nigeria 70: The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos; Strut, 2001 Ofo The Black Company, "Allah Wakbarr", Nigeria 70: The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos; Strut, 2001 Monomono, "Tire Loma Da Nigbehin", Nigeria 70: The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos; Strut, 2001 Sir Victor Uwaifo & His Melody Maestroes, "Akayan Ekassa", Nigeria 70: The Definitive Story of 1970's Funky Lagos; Strut, 2001 Bola Johnson & His Easy Life Top Beats, "Ezuku Buzo", Nigeria 70: Lagos Jump (Original Heavyweight Afrobeat, Highlife & Afro-Funk); Strut, 2008 Peacocks Guitar Band, "Eddie Quansa", Nigeria 70: Lagos Jump (Original Heavyweight Afrobeat, Highlife & Afro-Funk); Strut, 2008 Peter King, "African Dialects", Nigeria 70: Lagos Jump (Original Heavyweight Afrobeat, Highlife & Afro-Funk); Strut, 2008 Eric (Showboy) Akaeze & His Royal Ericos, "Wetin De Watch Goat, Goat Dey Watcham", Nigeria 70: Lagos Jump (Original Heavyweight Afrobeat, Highlife & Afro-Funk); Strut, 2008 Moneyman And The Super 5 International, "Life", Nigeria 70: Sweet Times (Afro-Funk, Highlife & Juju from 1970s Lagos); Strut, 2011 Tunde Mabadu, "Viva Disco (Instrumental)", Nigeria 70: Sweet Times (Afro-Funk, Highlife & Juju from 1970s Lagos); Strut, 2011 The Don Isaac Ezekial Combination, "Ire", Nigeria 70: Sweet Times (Afro-Funk, Highlife & Juju from 1970s Lagos); Strut, 2011 Soki Ohale's Uzzi, "Bisi's Beat", Nigeria 70: Sweet Times (Afro-Funk, Highlife & Juju from 1970s Lagos); Strut, 2011

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 18: "Jimmy McGriff"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week we take a listen to organist Jimmy McGriff, focusing on his work from the late 60's through the 70's. An innovative and tasteful player, McGriff could handle hard-hitting funk workouts as well as bluesy ballads, making full use of the many sounds the B-3 is capable of generating. With a recording and performing career that spanned nearly five decades, Jimmy McGriff was one of the undisputed masters of the Hammond organ. intro: Jimmy McGriff, "If You're Ready Come Go With Me", If You're Ready Come Go With Me: The Super Funk Collection; Groove Merchant, 1973 Jimmy McGriff, "Splanky", The Big Band; Solid State, 1966 Jimmy McGriff, "I've Got A Woman", I've Got A Woman; Solid State, 1967 Jimmy McGriff, "The Worm", The Worm; Solid State, 1968, Jimmy McGriff, "Kiko", Portrait; Blue Note/United Artists, 1973 Jimmy McGriff, "Criss Cross", Electric Funk; Blue Note, 1969 Jimmy McGriff, "The Bird", Groove Grease; Groove Merchant, 1971 Jimmy McGriff, "Blues For A Broken Down Funky Old Bus", Black And Blues; Groove Merchant, 1971 Jimmy McGriff, "The Now Thing", Soul Sugar; Capitol, 1971 Jimmy McGriff and Richard 'Groove' Holmes, "Brown Bread", Giants Of The Organ In Concert; Groove Merchant, 1972 Jimmy McGriff and Richard 'Groove' Holmes, "Finger Lickin' Good", Giants Of The Organ Come Together; Groove Merchant, 1973 Jimmy McGriff, "Purple Onion", Stump Juice; Groove Merchant, 1975 Jimmy McGriff, "Pogo's Stick", The Mean Machine; Groove Merchant, 1976 Jimmy McGriff, "Free And Foxy", Movin' Upside The Blues; JAM Records, 1982 Jimmy McGriff, "If You're Ready Come Go With Me", If You're Ready Come Go With Me: The Super Funk Collection; Groove Merchant, 1973

item.title: Dave Brubeck, 1920-2012
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: Today we learned the sad news that legendary jazz pianist and composer Dave Brubeck passed away a day shy of his 92nd birthday. To say that he moved to the beat of his own drummer would not be an understatement or cliche as many of Brubeck's most famous tunes were in non-standard time signatures (on his classic recordings from the 50's such as the seminal "Time Out", that drummer was Joe Morello). Brubeck's exploration of odd meters which he combined with a harmonic sensibility rooted in Classical music created a sound uniquely his own. I had the pleasure of seeing Brubeck perform a few years ago. He had to be helped on and off stage for each set but the music was still very much in his fingers. Despite his advanced age he played with a great deal of sensitivity, flawlessly executing the tricky phrasing of "Blue Rondo A La Turk". Periodically he'd rise and shuffle to the microphone to introduce the next song with a short anecdote. Brubeck didn't inspire a lot of imitators, which is a good thing. I'm not sure anyone else could do what he did quite as well.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 28: "2300 Skiddoo"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: Another episode that went long. That's two in a row, but we haven't heard any complaints. This week we step outside the usual Hot Can fare to listen to some of the most influential jazz pianists. The music spans the late-50's to the mid-80's and includes some expected names and others maybe a bit less so. Lots of trios: Ahmad Jamal, Bill Evans, Herbie Nichols and Keith Jarrett plus their respective rhythm sections each offer a unique take on this pared down format. intro: Booker T. and the MG's, "Hip Hug-Her", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Lennie Tristano, "Turkish Mambo", Requiem; Atlantic Records, 1981 Ahmad Jamal, "Ahmad's Blues", Jamal At The Penthouse; Argo, 1959 The Bill Evans Trio, "Blue In Green", Portrait In Jazz; Riverside, 1959 The Dave Brubeck Quartet, "World's Fair", Time Changes; Columbia Records, 1964 Herbie Nichols, "Blue Chopsticks", The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975 Herbie Nichols, "The Lady Sings The Blues", The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975 Herbie Nichols, "2300 Skiddoo", The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975 Herbie Nichols, "The Spinning Song", The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975 Andrew Hill, "One For One", One For One; Blue Note, 1975 Keith Jarrett, "Autumn Leaves", Standards Live; ECM, 1986 Thelonious Monk, "Straight, No Chaser", Straight, No Chaser; Columbia Records * - Linked to the the Allmusic entry for The Complete Blue Note Recordings instead which contains all of the tunes on The Third World plus alternate takes and has a more informative entry on Allmusic.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks, those must be some funky elevators you guys are riding! Pilsen vinyl jam sounds great, maybe after the holidays?

Nice change of pace from all that elevator music you've been putting us to sleep with. You finally brought the tropical Funk. Great job dirty!
Dirty Hunch, this is Amanda. Fantastic pics this week. You bring the Funk Veracruz style. You should come hang out with us on the southside. We have some vinyl junkie friends I think you would love to trade sounds with. We party on the southside better than the rest. Barbacoa and carnitas for breakfast after.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 42: "You'll Know When You Get There"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: Watch out for this one. Inspired by Bob Gluck's recent book "You'll Know When You Get There", we're going to spend the next two episodes spinning some of the deepest, most out-there space funk from Herbie Hancock and the Mwandishi Band. We'll trace the musical path that lead this group to the outer reaches of jazz group improvisation starting with Hancock's work as a leader for Blue Note and as a sideman for Miles Davis and Freddie Hubbard and ending up at Head Hunters, one of the most commercially successful jazz albums of all time. intro: Herbie Hancock, "Blind Man, Blind Man", The Blue Note Re-Issue Series; Blue Note, 1975 Herbie Hancock, "Maiden Voyage", Maiden Voyage; Blue Note, 1965 Miles Davis, "The Sorcerer", Sorcerer; Columbia Records, 1967 Freddie Hubbard, "The Intrepid Fox", Red Clay; CTI, 1970 Herbie Hancock, "Tell Me Bedtime Story", Fat Albert Rotunda; Warner Brothers, 1969 Herbie Hancock, "You'll Know When You Get There", Mwandishi; Warner Brothers, 1970 Herbie Hancock, "Ostinato (Suite For Angela)", Mwandishi; Warner Brothers, 1970 Herbie Hancock, "Quasar", Crossings; Warner Brothers, 1972 Booker T. And The M.G.'s, "Soul Limbo", single; Stax, 1965

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 43: "Hornets"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: This week we wrap up our exploration of the music Herbie Hancock made with the Mwandishi Band. If you're looking for more, dig up a copy of "Inside Out", the second album from Eddie Henderson and most of the Mwandishi Band. It was alluded to on the show but not mentioned by name. And be sure to check out Bob Gluck's book "You'll Know When You Get There" which tells the story of this great, oft-overlooked group. intro: Herbie Hancock, "Blind Man, Blind Man", The Blue Note Re-Issue Series; Blue Note, 1975 Herbie Hancock, "Water Torture", Crossings; Warner Brothers, 1972 Herbie Hancock, "Hornets", Sextant; Warner Brothers, 1973 Eddie Henderson, "Scorpio-Libra", Realization; Capricorn, 1973 Herbie Hancock, "The Spook Who Sat By The Door (Reprise)", The Spook Who Sat By The Door; 1973 Herbie Hancock, "Chameleon", Head Hunters; Warner Brothers, 1973 Booker T. And The M.G.'s, "Heads Or Tails", single; Stax, 1965

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 53: "The Facts From A To Z"
item.dc:creator: jasonconny
item.content:encoded: It's the one year anniversary of The Hot Can All Vinyl Power and to commemorate the occasion we're putting up our first episode dedicated to a single song: "Sunny" by Bobby Hebb. In addition to Hebb's original (and two alternate versions Hebb cut in '75!), we've put together a pretty diverse collection of covers ranging from mainstays of The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour to a few musicians who are being featured for the first time. As one of the most frequently covered songs in popular music (second only to "Yesterday" perhaps?), "Sunny" has been a favorite of ours since the beginning. With it's bouncing melody, optimistic lyrics and funky groove, what's not to love? Be sure to listen to this one for details on the first ever Hot Can prize giveaway! It's our way of thanking you for listening to the show. intro: Herbie Hancock, "Blind Man, Blind Man", The Blue Note Re-Issue Series; Blue Note, 1975 Bobby Hebb, "Sunny", single; Philips, 1966 Les McCann,  "Sunny Part I", Les McCann Plays The Hits; Limelight, 1966 James Brown, "Sunny", Gettin' Down To It; King, 1969 Booker T. and the MG's, "Sunny", Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967 Henry Cain, "Sunny", The Funky Organ-ization of Henry Cain; Capitol Records, 1968 Brother Jack McDuff and David 'Fathead' Newman, "Sunny", Double Barrelled Soul; Atlantic Records, 1967 Les McCann, "Sunny Part II", Les McCann Plays The Hits; Limelight, 1966 Frank Sinatra and Duke Ellington, "Sunny", Francis A. & Edward K.; Reprise, 1967 Wes Montgomery, "Sunny", California Dreamin'; Verve, 1966 Pat Martino, "Sunny", Live!; Muse Records, 1972 Rufus Harley, "Sunny", A Tribute To Courage; Atlantic Records, 1967 The New Lime, "Sunny", single; Minaret, 1968 Bobby Hebb, "Sunny ('76)", single; Laurie Records, 1975 Boney M., "Sunny", single; Atco, 1976 Bobby Hebb, "Sunny (Disco)", single; Laurie Records, 1975
